Arts Foundation in the Visual Arts
Description:
Materials fee: $30.
This introductory course is designed as a wide-ranging overview of the world of visual arts through drawing and two- and three-dimensional design. You will gain knowledge from a series of hands-on projects to improve technical skills and compositional layout through media such as pencil, cardboard, charcoal, collage, digital programs on tablets, ink, and painting You will discuss visual art from a historical and contemporary context, studying past artwork in class and through exhibitions showcased in The Gallery at the Rhodes Arts Center. Prepare to dive deeply into fascinating topics like color theory, reflect on the creative process, and write about art. You will learn concepts, technical skills, and vocabulary that will prepare you to confidently enroll in any visual art course in the future.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. 9th-grade students are required to choose this course or ART 111P.

Description: In this course, you will learn how to use video as an artistic medium by developing skills and creating your own individual video works. You will take your work from the idea stage to a finished work by designing projects with artistic intent, using tools such as storyboards, shot lists, and post-production editing. You will explore visual art design composition and apply visual terminology to your work. In discussions of individual videos and critiques of finished projects, you will learn how to interpret and describe them using the vocabulary of art and design. Not only will you learn technical skill and artistic theory, but you will develop your ability to think visually and solve problems creatively.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description:
Materials fee: $80.
In this hands-on visual art class, you will be introduced to color theory and the painting process. You will learn how to observe and identify value, color intensity, and color temperature. You will experiment with layering approaches for building up a painting as well as wet-into-wet alla prima painting techniques. You will learn design vocabulary around composition, atmospheric perspective, color mixing, and concepts for suggesting the illusion of dimensionality and space. Subject matter will include still life, the human figure, and landscape. Oil paint is the principal medium utilized in this class, though charcoal and acrylic paint are also used. In addition, you will be exposed to a wide variety of contemporary and traditional trends in painting to both inform and inspire your own work.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description:
Materials fee: $30.
Drawing is a fundamental practice for a visual artist and is a skill that can be learned. In this course, you will be introduced to a wide variety of drawing approaches, including perspective drawing, contour line drawing, quick- and long-pose figure drawing, portraiture, and landscape sketching in the field. You will explore drawing and design challenges with a variety of media, including graphite, charcoal, conté crayon, ink, paint, and scratchboard. This class will greatly improve your drawing abilities and overall confidence in the visual arts and prepare you for other visual art courses. In addition to visual vocabulary, you will be exposed to a wide variety of contemporary and traditional trends in drawing.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description:
Materials fee: $50.
What exactly makes something “good design”? Ever wonder how this concept fits into the art world? This introductory course takes you on a journey of discovering a variety of media to push the envelope of how design is composed effectively. Projects can include using printmaking, pen and ink, collage, mixed media, fiber art, and even drawing to help you gain a wider understanding of the elements and principles of design. Where you see design in the world isn’t always what you think: You will learn about two-dimensional design from a contemporary, cultural, and historical lens, as well as learn more about genres like illustration and graphic art. You will be encouraged to develop your own style and use critical awareness as a base for visual expression
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description:
Materials fee: $65
In this course, similar to Drawing and Composition I, you will be introduced to rudimentary skill-building drawing exercises. Additionally, the class will explore trends in illustration and design found in contemporary graphic novels and children’s books to inspire visual narratives focusing attention on diversity, equity, and inclusion. Unique to this art class is the opportunity to combine creative writing with visual art-making as you develop your unique perspectives and visual voice. Art media will include graphite, charcoal, watercolor, gouache, acrylic, ink, collage, and assemblage.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description:
Materials fee: $70.
This course examines the use of clay as an artistic medium through projects that employ both hand-building and wheel-throwing techniques. These include pinching and coiling, as well as wheel-throwing cylinders, bowls, plates, and mugs. You can choose to make ceramic sculpture and/or functional work while learning construction techniques, glazing, and surface decoration skills. An independent final project will serve as an assessment of your skills, and you will be well-prepared to develop your own work in upper-level classes. Historical, contemporary, and cultural perspectives on ceramics will also be explored, and the development of a personal style is encouraged.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description: Have you ever wondered what graphic designers do? This studio course studies digital media and graphic design as visual art. You will learn the basics of Adobe Illustrator and how to build compositions using text layouts and other vector-based images. You will even use your talents to make promotional materials for school events and see your work around campus. Visual thinking and creative problem-solving are emphasized as you build on a foundation of artistic vocabulary and technical skills. You will learn the basics of color theory and how digital media is used in today’s world, specifically through advertising, marketing, logo design, and typography.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description:
Materials fee: $120.
Do you want the pictures you take to look great? This course will help you do that, whether you use an SLR camera with manual settings or your phone. As you learn the basics of darkroom photography, you’ll finally understand some of those esoteric terms you’ve heard, like f-stop and shutter speed. After this course, you will have all the tools you need to imaginatively and creatively make compelling images. You will discuss individual images and learn how to interpret and describe them using the vocabulary of art to apply principles of design. The course covers photographic methods, materials, and equipment, strongly emphasizing technical and procedural proficiency in the darkroom.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: Students must supply their own 35mm camera with manual-exposure capability. (The school has a limited number of cameras available to rent if a student does not own one. Rental fee is $50 a semester for maintenance of the equipment.)

This course will give you an introduction to basic skills and concepts in three-dimensional art through a number of hands-on projects.You will explore a variety of materials and processes. Possible projects include wire sculpture, stone carving, clay modeling, life-size plaster casting, mold-making, and the creative altering of old books. Discussions and research related to sculptural theory and art historical context will provide a richer understanding of past and present shifts in the art world. A working literacy of the elements and principles of design vocabulary as it relates to three-dimensional art will help you to further develop your capacity for critical thinking and dialogue. This course will prepare you for independent work exploring your own interests in three-dimensional art.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

If you are a student with a keen interest in the visual arts, you will especially enjoy this full-credit class. You will be given instruction in drawing, design, painting, collage, assemblage, and mixed media. Creativity and risk-taking are encouraged. This course will provide technical instruction, arts vocabulary, and exposure to a wide variety of traditional and contemporary trends in areas of drawing, painting, and design to inform and inspire your own artwork.

You will use your existing skills in working with clay to develop your own artwork. If your projects lend themselves to advanced techniques in hand-building or wheel-throwing, these will be taught. You will use a sketchbook to develop ideas, problem-solve, collect sources and inspiration, reflect, and explore other artists’ work that relates to your interests.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ART 306 or permission of instructor.

Description: Materials fee: $80.
Credit: The symbiotic interrelationship of drawing and painting is the primary focus of this full-credit advanced-level course. As an experienced art student, you will spend class time and open studio time exploring a challenging array of visual art exercises utilizing a wide variety of drawing and painting media, including graphite, charcoal, pastel, conté crayon, ink, collage, scratchboard, watercolor, acrylic, and oil paint. You will be given comprehensive instruction in numerous drawing and painting approaches as you investigate still life, the human form, architecture, plein air landscape, and portraiture. In addition, you will receive tailored support for your own unique, thematic investigation. Specialized instruction will be offered in color theory, color, painting techniques, visual art presentation, and individualized portfolio preparation.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ART 302, ART 303, or permission of instructor through portfolio application process.

Description:
Materials fee: $75.
This college-level course is for highly motivated juniors and seniors who are seriously interested in the study of three-dimensional art. Through experimentation, revision, critiques, and guidance from the instructor, you will engage in the artistic process and develop a cohesive body of work exploring a theme of your choice. Any number of three-dimensional media and processes may be used, including clay, wire, wood, stone, assemblage, installation, fibers, foam board, cardboard, and digital modeling. Your work will be photographed for use in a portfolio for college application or personal enrichment, and you will be exposed to professional artists and recent graduates whose work relates to yours.
Prerequisite: Prerequisites: ART 306, ART 317, or permission of the instructor through portfolio application process.

Description:
Biology builds your understanding of the molecules and substances important to cell structure and function, expands to genetics and organismal biology, and focuses on evolution and ecology. You will use a variety of approaches to explore and learn the principles and concepts of biology, with emphasis on how biological systems work and, ultimately, how a whole organism depends on cellular processes. You will participate in class discussions, small-group projects, and presentations and will conduct laboratory investigations. For some units of study, you can choose a specific topic to research or design a lab procedure to explore your own question. You will work throughout the semester to develop metacognitive abilities like study skills, research, citation, and note-taking.
If you are a sophomore taking Biology, you have the opportunity to participate in an interdisciplinary travel program. Recent destinations include South Africa, Brazil, and Spain/Morocco. You simultaneously enroll in three courses for the semester: Humanities II: World History, Humanities II: World Religions, and Biology. There is a formal application process, and participation requires additional fees.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: A previous high school course in science. Open to sophomores and juniors who have not yet taken biology at the high-school level. Students are strongly encouraged to complete Biology before Chemistry. Placement based on screening process.

Description: You will study human body systems with an emphasis on the relationship between structure, function, and homeostatic regulation. You will conduct laboratory investigations, perform dissections, and design projects to learn about body systems in depth, discovering the connections between them. Final projects are student-designed and explore a system or topic in depth. Expect to teach your peers in this student-centered course.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: BIO 311 or equivalent. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.

Description: In Biotechnology, you will explore the theory and techniques employed by living systems to build biomolecules and interact with the world, and you will practice some of those methods in the lab. A central theme is the study of DNA and proteins. You will learn laboratory techniques to isolate, quantify, replicate, and manipulate DNA. You will learn about cell culture, expression and purification of proteins, and use of enzymes and other biological reagents. Your class will function as a research group in which each student both works on projects independently and collaborates as part of a team to achieve common learning targets. Emphasis will be placed on research and presentation, both written and oral, and will interweave topics of ethics and social justice.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: A- or better in BIO 311, CHE 311, and MAT 311; B+ or better in honors equivalents. Strong reading and writing skills are also required. Open to students who meet the prerequisites or receive departmental approval.

Description: Field biology is a sub-discipline that focuses on the ecological branch of biology. In this college-level course, you will explore biological organization and function through species, populations, communities, and ecosystems while developing rich scientific skills as you learn what it means to be a scientific researcher. You will also have opportunities to expand your knowledge of other fields of biology, including but not limited to cellular biology, genetics, botany, and animal behavior, to understand ecological relationships more deeply. An overarching theme of this course will be consideration of how life around us is changing and will continue to respond to our changing climate.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: A- or better in BIO 311, CHE 311, and MAT 311; B+ or better in honors equivalents. Strong reading and writing skills are also required. Open to students who meet the prerequisites or receive departmental approval.

Description: In this laboratory-based course, you will delve into the study of matter and the changes that it undergoes by examining topics such as atomic structure, periodicity, and bonding; names, formulas, and reactions of chemical substances; the mole concept and stoichiometry; thermo-chemistry; aqueous solutions; kinetic theory; and gas behavior. Prerequisite: Prerequisites: B+ or better in all previous high school science courses. A- or better in MAT311 or B+ or better MAT 321, or equivalents. Biology background is strongly recommended. Open to sophomores, juniors, seniors, and PGs. Placement based on screening process.

Description: In this fast-paced, quantitatively intensive introductory course, you will tackle a comprehensive list of topics in chemistry, including solutions chemistry, kinetics, equilibrium, and acid-base chemistry, in addition to the topics listed in the description for CHE 311. You will solve complex practical problems to refine skills such as theory generation, mathematical modeling and problem-solving, and experimental design with quantitative equipment.
Prerequisite: Prerequisites: B+ or better in all previous high school science courses. A- or better in MAT311 or B+ or better MAT 321, or equivalents. Biology background is strongly recommended. Open to sophomores, juniors, seniors, and PGs. Placement based on screening process.

Credit: In this half-credit course, you will extend your exposure to laboratory work in chemistry beyond first-year chemistry and prepare for advanced-level coursework in chemistry. You will learn how to design experiments using specified equipment and probes, write robust lab reports, and conduct authentic practical inquiries. You will work on quantitative experiments (titrations, mass analysis, etc.) as well as qualitative experiments (chromatography, emission spectrum, etc.).
Prerequisite: Prerequisites: MAT 311 and CHE 311 or equivalent. Students who have taken CHE 321 are not eligible.

Description: You will build upon your knowledge from Honors Chemistry in this college-level course. After a quick review of introductory topics, you will be ready for a deeper look at atomic structure, chemical bonding, reactivity, thermodynamics, kinetics, equilibrium, and electrochemistry. A college-level text is used. Laboratory work is an integral part of the course. Advanced Chemistry will introduce you to the content on the AP Chemistry exam, but additional studying on your own would be necessary to be successful on the AP exam.
Prerequisite: Prerequisites: B+ or better in PHY 211 and MAT 411 or equivalents. B+ or better in CHE 321 or A- or better in CHE 311 and CHE 415. Open to students who meet the prerequisites or receive departmental approval.

Description: In this advanced college-level course, you will apply the chemistry of equilibrium, kinetics, thermodynamics, and reactivity to the environment. You will study atmospheric chemistry and pollution, energy and climate change, water chemistry and pollution, and toxic compounds. You will also evaluate the effects of anthropogenic activities on Earth’s systems.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: B or better in CHE 521 or equivalent. Open to students who meet the prerequisites or departmental approval.

Description: Chinese I is an introductory-level course for which you do not need any background in the language. The goal of this course is to help you develop functional communication in spoken and written Mandarin Chinese. The curriculum is designed to assist you in gaining linguistic, social, and cultural background knowledge of the Chinese language and to help you develop strategies and study habits to strengthen your skills in interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational communication. You will learn to use Pinyin (Mandarin Romanization) and Chinese characters, as you learn to communicate about daily life and other topics of interest and cultural significance.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description: This course builds upon the foundation of Chinese I. The goal is to help you increase your vocabulary, broaden your knowledge of grammar, and be better able to use your Chinese in everyday situations. The curriculum is designed to enhance the accuracy of your pronunciation, develop understanding of the etymology and basic structures of Chinese characters, and foster effective study habits for developing skills in interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational communication. Besides developing functional language skills, you will learn how to use online tools to assist your language learning, while continuing to explore Chinese culture.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: CHI 111 or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Description: If you have demonstrated a higher level of language skill and greater interest in the study of Chinese, this course is appropriate for you. The content explores themes similar to Chinese II, but you will learn more vocabulary and be able to communicate in greater depth. You will sharpen your pronunciation accuracy, develop character-writing skills, understand the etymology of characters, expand your vocabulary, and learn more grammar. Your skills in interpersonal, interpretive, and presentational communication will be emphasized equally.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: CHI 111 or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Description: Building upon the foundation of Chinese II, the goal of the course is to enhance your use of Mandarin in more complex situations. Your listening and speaking opportunities will be increased through the use of a broader range of materials beyond the textbook. You will work on projects to improve your written and speaking skills. The class will be conducted mostly in Chinese, with Chinese films and written cultural material increasingly incorporated into the curriculum.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: CHI 211 or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Description: Building upon Chinese II, the goal of this course is to enhance your use of Mandarin in more complex situations. If you have demonstrated a higher level of language skill and greater interest in the study of Chinese, this course is appropriate for you. The content is similar to Chinese 311, but you will learn more vocabulary and grammatical structures. Your listening and speaking opportunities will be increased through the use of a broader range of materials beyond the textbook. You will work on projects to improve your writing and speaking skills. The class is conducted mostly in Chinese, with a greater degree of authentic material incorporated into the curriculum.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: CHI 211, CHI 221, or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Description: This advanced course is conducted in Chinese. The objective of the course is to move you from controlled speaking situations to more independent, open conversation on a variety of topics, including current events and social issues. More complex sentence structures will be introduced, allowing discourse on broader topics. You will be given opportunities to read authentic materials to explore your interests in Chinese culture and language and you will give presentations on your research.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: CHI 311 or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Description: If you have demonstrated a higher level of language skills and greater interest in the study of Chinese, this course is appropriate for you. This advanced-level course is similar to Chinese 411, but you will explore topics in greater detail. This course is conducted entirely in Chinese. The objective of this course is to move you from controlled speaking situations to more independent, open dialogue. The topics that you will encounter include current events and social issues in the Chinese-speaking world. More complex sentence structures are introduced, allowing for discourse on broader topics. You will be introduced to classical Chinese and the role it plays in the modern language. You will read authentic materials to explore your interests in Chinese culture and language, culminating in presentations on your research.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: CHI 311, CHI 321, or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Course Name: Advanced Studies in Chinese I: Contemporary China and Chinese Culture
Description: This course focuses on Chinese culture and its evolution via a survey of history, geography, education, literature, philosophy, customs, arts, and politics. After reading culturally relevant articles and watching contemporary Chinese films or dramatic productions, you will explore Chinese people’s contemporary life and understand Chinese culture by doing research, discussing cultural phenomena, interviewing native speakers, and working on projects. The course provides you with opportunities to achieve proficiency across three modes of communication (interpretive, interpersonal, and presentational). The course is conducted entirely in Chinese. With some review of supplemental material outside of class, this course will prepare you for the AP Chinese language and culture exam.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: CHI 411, CHI 421, or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Course Name: Advanced Studies in Chinese II: Chinese Literature
Description:
CHI 611  Advanced Studies in Chinese II: Chinese Literature
This advanced course delves deeply into Chinese literature. The course explores texts from ancient China up to the present, with a special emphasis on contemporary and modern Chinese literature. The course will be conducted in Chinese. If Chinese is your first language and you would like to study literature in Chinese, this is the appropriate level for you.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: CHI 522 or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Description: In Introduction to Computer Programming, you will explore the basics of Java and Python, two powerful programming languages, through the creation of simple games and graphical programs. This hands-on approach will not only teach you programming fundamentals, including conditionals, loops, arrays, and basic object orientation, but also enhance your logical and critical-thinking skills. The course culminates in an open-ended project, allowing you to apply your new skills in a creative manner, with the flexibility to explore both languages in your final work.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description: In Discrete Math with Python, you will explore the intersection of mathematics and computer science, building on your precalculus foundation to study mathematical sets, algorithms, sequences and sums, and vectors and matrices. While focusing on the theory behind these concepts, you will use the programming language Python to enhance your understanding through practical applications. You will build a solid foundation in computer science and coding in Python, as well as an improved understanding of functions.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: MAT 411 or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

Description: Advanced Computer Science will provide you with an entry to a higher understanding of computer science through projects and collaboration. You will learn about the history and use of computer science, syntax and style of typed and non-typed languages, and data structures. More advanced topics will include studies of algorithms to solve computational problems, the introduction to machine learning, recursion, and data modeling.
Prerequisite: Prerequisites: CMP 312 and MAT 411, equivalent, or departmental approval. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.

Course Name: Honors Ballet I: Technique and Theory
Description:
Honors Ballet I offers a rigorous and immersive study of ballet, emphasizing both technical training and a deeper understanding of its historical and physical foundations. Through a comprehensive exploration of ballet’s global history, dancers will examine how the form has evolved and continues to shape and be shaped by contemporary perspectives.
This course places a strong emphasis on ballet technique, focusing on alignment, artistry, and injury prevention through the study of anatomy and kinesiology. Dancers will refine their strength, precision, and musicality while developing the ability to execute longer, more complex movement sequences. Alongside physical training, students will engage in critical reflection — through writing, discussion, and practice — on how ballet informs personal identity and how they, in turn, contribute to its ongoing evolution.
Credit: Designed for dancers with prior ballet experience, this yearlong course provides one half-credit and may be repeated by students who seek continued technical and artistic growth.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: Audition/interview with instructor.

Required one-term cocurricular for 10th-graders
.
The Diversity and Social Justice seminar focuses on improving intergroup relations by breaking down existing barriers as well as developing an appreciation of the diverse identities within the NMH community and the greater world. You will engage in discussions, interactive activities, and deep reflection to achieve the three course goals: 1) increasing personal awareness, providing you the opportunity to learn more about your own social awareness and identities, 2) expanding knowledge, providing you with information about the identities of others as well as helping you develop familiarity with social and historical issues of diversity, and 3) encouraging action, helping you to see yourself as an agent of change toward creating a more just and equitable world. The grade for this course appears on the NMH transcript at the end of the fall or spring semester. It is not factored into the NMH GPA, but it does influence calculations for some academic awards.

Required of all 9th-graders except those enrolled in the ESOL program.
Ninth-grade English is part of the Humanities I program, which asks you to explore four essential questions: Who am I? What is my place? What does it mean to be human? How, then, shall I live? While developing the skills necessary to succeed on your NMH literary journey, you will repeatedly return to these essential questions. The English portion of the Humanities I program, which complements the work done in the religious studies and philosophy portion of the course, has two primary goals: to build an inclusive community of learners and to develop skills and habits for reading, writing, discussion, and critical thinking. You will read and discuss works of literature that seek to answer the four essential questions. You will support others and receive their support during poetry recitations, discussions, and classroom activities. You will practice writing in response to the reading, and you will have the opportunity to tell your own stories by writing personal narratives.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description:
Required of all 10th-graders except those enrolled in the ESOL program.
In this course, you will read literature from around the world and continue to develop the skills of critical reading, writing, and discussion. You will practice reading with close attention and grounding interpretations in concrete textual detail. Discussion is central to this course and becomes increasingly student-directed. A variety of informal writing exercises will help you to continue to develop your ability to express yourself clearly, and you will write (and revise) both personal and analytical essays. Readings will explore multiple genres –– drama, fiction, poetry –– and a wide range of authors, cultivating your appreciation for the richness and diversity of literature from around the world and developing a global perspective.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

You will practice reading with close attention and grounding interpretations in concrete textual detail. Discussion is central to this course and becomes increasingly student-directed. A variety of informal writing exercises will help you to continue to develop your ability to express yourself clearly, and you will write (and revise) both personal and analytical essays. Readings will explore multiple genres –– drama, fiction, poetry –– and a wide range of authors, cultivating your appreciation for the richness and diversity of literature from around the world and developing a global perspective.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description: You will write daily in this introductory-level elective, experimenting in various forms of creative writing that may include poetry, short stories, flash fiction, plays, and creative nonfiction. You will also read model texts with emphasis on the study of craft. This course emphasizes the creative writing process: sharing work with each other, producing multiple drafts, and critiquing. By the end of the semester, you will produce a collection, manuscript, or portfolio of work for assessment.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description: Find relevant stories, ask good questions, write powerful sentences: These three endeavors comprise the core of quality journalism. Each also requires a ton of practice. In this class –– through your own reporting as well as close reading of published journalism –– you will develop skills in interviewing, story-finding, pitch-writing, scene construction, character development, descriptive writing, and thematic layering. You will conclude the semester with an ambitious independent reporting project on a topic of your choosing. Emphasis will be placed on planning and structuring independent, multistep projects, a set of skills that you will find transferable to numerous disciplines beyond journalism.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description:
Open to juniors.
In American Literature, you will continue to develop and extend the skills taught in the first two years. The course examines particularly American themes, traditions, and voices. You will closely analyze literary texts, focusing on an author’s craft and exploring the relationship between form and content. Reading, informal writing-to-think practices, and discussion –– which by now is largely student-directed –– form the backbone of your daily work in class. Formal writing assignments, which emphasize the use of evidence in clear, coherent prose, may include assignments in the personal and/or creative modes, but the focus is on sustained literary analysis that builds on your close-reading skills.

Credit: This half-credit course will introduce you to the basic vocabulary of film analysis and allow you to use this vocabulary to write analytically about film. Over the course of the semester, you will develop a deeper understanding of how films are produced and how they create meaning. The course will ask you to take a step back and appreciate film not only for its entertainment value but also for the quality of its production and visual/aesthetic coherence. You will watch and discuss films from a variety of genres, cultures, and time periods. Be prepared to step outside of your comfort zone!
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Course Name: Multimedia Production: Making an Arts, News, and Culture Magazine
Description: This course is a deep dive into the collaborative production of a contemporary arts, news, and culture magazine. You will have numerous opportunities to tackle the practical and ethical problems that are inherent to making relevant media in a complicated world. You will work across media, including print, digital, and podcasting. You will produce your own nonfiction projects in writing, audio, illustration, and/or photojournalism while also developing the editorial skills required to work collaboratively on everything from layout, content, and style to the ultimate mission of a publication. Every student in the course will contribute to the production of NMH’s own periodical, the Lamplighter. The course is required for all Lamplighter editors.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Open to sophomores, juniors, seniors, and PGs who have taken Journalism or completed a term of the Lamplighter cocurricular.

Description: Postgraduates will dive deeply into the literary arts in this course. You will get extensive practice in language study (vocabulary and grammar), writing styles, active reading, and public speaking. Postgraduates come to NMH from varied academic backgrounds, and teachers of this course recognize these variations and adjust assignments, discussions, and study techniques to fit your needs, moving toward a standard of work commensurate with the college level. Limited to postgraduates, the course provides a comfortable setting in which postgraduates support and bond with one another. You can expect a varied reading load of novels, stories, contemporary drama, and a selection of poems and essays. Writing assignments range from personal essays to formal, academic analysis.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Open to PGs.

Description: This course is designed for postgraduate and other students who need additional support and time to develop skills in reading and writing at the college level. Using writing-to-learn strategies, you will read a variety of challenging texts, including poetry, drama, novels, and nonfiction. You will practice the fundamentals of effective writing by composing your own essays in a range of genres, from analytical to persuasive to personal narrative, with the goal of becoming a clearer, more organized, more confident writer. By exploring and engaging in a writing process that includes generating ideas, writing to learn, drafting, collaboration, revising, and reflecting on your own work, you will become more aware of your own agency as a writer and thinker. As in all of our English courses, you will also be asked to engage regularly in collaborative, seminar-style discussions about the readings.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 413 for PGs or any 300-level English course for juniors. Does not satisfy the senior year English requirement. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.

Course Name: English Seminar: The Art of Creative Nonfiction
Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
We are all experienced storytellers. Narrative is how we make sense of experience. But why are some stories we hear or read more compelling than others? This is a course about telling true stories, otherwise known as creative nonfiction. Through extensive reading, discussion, and writing, you will become well-versed in this genre and hone your ability to write your own creative nonfiction. You will ask what constitutes a “true” story and what it means for it to be “well told.” What is the relationship between literary truth and factual truth? What are the literary tools at a nonfiction writer’s disposal? What makes stories like these work on us — or not? Course readings will introduce you to some of the many forms that this broad and flexible genre takes. Through close reading and analysis of these texts, you will explore how writers use their experiences and observations to convey authentic stories and make artful commentary. Readings will also serve as models of technique and style to draw on in your own writing projects. Mining your own life and the world around you for inspiration, you will write creative nonfiction pieces in a variety of forms, such as personal narratives, profiles, philosophical meditations, and hybrid texts. Throughout the semester, you will share full drafts of your writing projects with the class, and you will read each other’s work constantly and critically. Studied authors may include Elizabeth Alexander, Joan Didion, Chang-Rae Lee, Leslie Jamison, Zadie Smith, Teju Cole, Eula Biss, Amy Tan, Ross Gay, Annie Dillard, David Foster Wallace, James Wood, Mako Yoshikawa, James Baldwin, Janet Malcolm, E.B. White, Tim O’Brien, Amy Tan, and others.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
Shakespeare’s revenge tragedies, histories, comedies, and romances have been read, performed, and studied closely in schools around the world. This course will give you an intimate knowledge of the plays and poetry of William Shakespeare through reading his work. You will consider Shakespeare’s ideas about leadership and loyalty, race and gender, love and friendship. You will write regularly through in-class exercises, short essays, and occasional longer papers. Regular reading aloud and in-class scene work will be part of the course. You will study and compare film adaptations of the plays, and each student will present information to the class on Shakespeare, Elizabethan England, or related topics
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
If you enjoy reading, want to immerse your imagination in the world of words, and want to spend time with authors who have defined the art of writing, this is the course for you. This course offers something increasingly rare: the chance to single-task, devoting your full attention to reading for several hours a week. You will read novels –– big novels ––  that have influenced individuals and cultures for decades, even centuries. We’ll inhabit these “big books” together, collectively mapping the world of each book and attempting to fathom its laws. We’ll also immerse ourselves in its intricacies, and you will have opportunities to become engrossed by your own little corners –– particular passages or threads or curiosities –– of each book-world in question. You will learn to read more deeply and with greater attention to detail, language, structure, and formal features. Along the way, you will develop a stronger capacity for attention and a richer experience of it. Expect rigorous reading assignments and dynamic, student-directed, seminar-style discussions. You will write frequent personal responses to the reading, literary analyses employing techniques of observation and discovery, and one or two papers for which you will choose the topic and format.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Course Name: English Seminar: Reading and Writing Short Fiction
Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
You should write because you love the shape of stories and sentences and the creation of different words on a page. Writing comes from reading, and reading is the finest teacher of how to write.
-Annie Proulx
This course is based on the belief that close reading and writing fuel one another. You will explore the nature and design of fiction by reading a range of short fictional works and by writing both critically and creatively. You will learn to read like a writer, dismantling stories and inspecting their component parts –– plot, narrative point of view, character, setting, style, etc. –– in order to develop your understanding of the foundational elements of storytelling and the design of narrative. You will pay close attention to the purposes and functions of language, to the relationships between reading and writing, and to narrative as a mode of thinking and an expression of culture. The work for this course integrates multiple modes: You will write critically about short fiction, and you will also compose your own stories, incorporating techniques and ideas inspired by the course readings. Come with an open mind about sharing your writing: You will regularly share works in progress with the class, and you will be responsible for responding to each other’s work. Authors may include Alice Munro, Tim O’Brien, Gabriel García Márquez, Lorrie Moore, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Raymond Carver, Haruki Murakami, Margaret Atwood, Amy Tan, Tobias Wolff, E. M. Forster, James Baldwin, Amy Hempel, Rick Moody, Jamaica Kincaid, Ursula K. Le Guin, Ottessa Moshfegh, Helen Oyeyemi, Lydia Davis, George Saunders, and others.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Course Name: English Seminar: Global Women's Literature: Mothers, Sisters, Daughters Speak
English Seminar: The Bible as Literature
Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
As a reader of the Bible, you join millions of other people across time and place who have read and been influenced by its words and ideas.The Bible is a major cultural touchstone and a source for ideas and styles that echo throughout works of literature from all over the world. This course will introduce you to a literary approach to the Bible, concentrating on careful readings of selections from the Hebrew Bible and the New Testament. Although it is impossible to read and discuss the Bible without reference to religion, the purpose of this course is to study the Bible not as a sacred text but as a complex literary work. As such, you will grapple with the content and the literary function of the biblical texts using the same techniques used to analyze any other complex literary work. What choices in form, style, and content shape the text, and what are the effects of those choices? How do structures, patterns, and the artful use of language and literary devices work to create meaning? Close, careful reading and discussion are central to this course, so be ready to read and engage actively –– and to do so with an attitude of curiosity, openness, and appreciation of multiple interpretive perspectives. Written work will include informal in-class exercises, short weekly responses, and longer, focused analytical essays.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Description: Power is a ubiquitous concept, yet how well do you really understand it? You may be good at identifying those who have it and those who don’t, but when asked what makes a person powerful, many find the answer is elusive. In this course, you will interrogate the concept of power. The voices of the powerless are often overlooked or spoken over. Here you will have an opportunity to hear those stories, examine how power is explored through fiction, and draw conclusions about structures of power. You may read texts about individuals overthrowing regimes, witches identifying and coming into their power, and other characters asserting their strength. While the characters in these texts dismantle systems of oppression, so too shall you, by making connections to contemporary issues. Readings may include Pierce Brown’s “Red Rising,” Margaret Atwood’s “The Handmaid’s Tale,” Madeline Miller’s “Circe,” and George Orwell’s “1984,” in addition to short stories and poetry.
Credit: Half credit. Option to earn advanced (500-level) credit.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.

Course Name: English Seminar: Reading and Writing The Land
English Seminar: Coming of Age: Reading the Bildungsroman
Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
This course explores the transition from youth to adulthood and its representation in literature. The period of time between adolescence and adulthood is often regarded as the most influential period in a person’s development. In literature, the bildungsroman, or coming-of-age novel, explores this transition, tracing the movement from the innocence of childhood to the knowledge and awareness of maturity. In this class, you will read books that investigate what it means to grow up, leave home, seek adventure, weather disappointments, and contend with one’s origins –– and what it means to grapple with change itself. How is identity shaped by the events of adolescence? What is involved in the transformation from adolescence into adulthood? How is the transition to adulthood imagined across time periods, literary genres, and differing points of view? How does reading literature shape and provide insight into our own identities? You will wrestle with these questions through class discussion and in a combination of analytical, personal, and creative writing pieces. Readings may include “On Earth We’re Briefly Gorgeous,” by Ocean Vuong; “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man,” by James Joyce; “We the Animals,” by Justin Torres; “Nervous Conditions,” by Tsitsi Dangarembga; “Never Let Me Go,” by Kazuo Ishiguro; “The Secret History,” by Donna Tartt; and “Invisible Man,” by Ralph Ellison.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
I stood at the border; I stood at the edge and claimed it as central. I claimed it as central, and let the rest of the world move over to where I was.
— Toni Morrison
Borders — the imaginary lines that separate one nation from another, one community from another, us from them — have a profound impact on the lives and experiences of those who live within them as well as those who cross them. Ideas about borders play a complex role in our current understandings of race, class, gender, and citizenship. In this course you will read literature that explores borders and border-crossings — geographic, social, and perceptual; some literal, some psychological, some metaphorical — in order to consider what it means to live life “on the border.” Themes include migration, xenophobia, indigeneity, and concepts of home, foreignness, otherness, and belonging. How are borders constructed, and how are they transgressed? What makes a border appear threatening or inviting, liberatory or oppressive? How do personal and social identities play a role in who gets to cross which borders, and how safely? What does it mean to be shaped and informed by multiple places, homes, languages, or senses of self? What terrain — physically, culturally, emotionally — do writers inhabit when they write about borders? In this course, you will explore the ways that reading, writing, and thinking about borders, whether literal or metaphorical ones, complicate the way we understand identity, community, belonging, and citizenship. Like the literature you read, the writing you do in this course will dwell in the borderlands. By composing in forms that blend critical reading, narrative, personal reflection, and multimedia, you will think and write about others’ border crossings as well as your own.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Course Name: English Seminar: Comic Studies and Theory
Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
The graphic novel has emerged as one of the principal narrative modes of our time, but putting words and pictures together is as old as writing itself. In this course, you will read contemporary graphic fiction and nonfiction alongside essays by scholars, creators, and critics that explore the interplay of visual and textual elements in graphic storytelling. You will also study the theory surrounding how comics — the contemporary term for graphic fiction and nonfiction — are created and understood. You’ll read at least one novel alongside its graphic adaptation, examining what’s gained — and what’s lost — in the transition between these narrative forms. You will explore how comics convey meaning and develop an understanding of the “grammar” involved in reading a panel, page, and sequence. You will examine the complex relationship between comics and conventional fiction and how comics relate to other forms of visual art and sequential narrative. You will write several critical essays and personal narratives and produce a substantial graphic narrative, with an in-depth analysis of your aesthetic choices, as your final product for the course.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Course Name: English Seminar: Reading and Writing Poetry
Description:
Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
Emily Dickinson wrote, “If I read a book and it makes my whole body so cold no fire can warm me, I know that is poetry. If I feel physically as if the top of my head were taken off, I know that is poetry.” In this course, you will chase that sensorial experience, in the hopes of emerging at the end of the semester knowing poetry with the whole of your being. This course will be a deep dive into both the reading and writing of poetry. You will study poetry that spans countries, centuries, and modalities. You will spend the semester unpacking the what and how of this literary genre, asking of each poem you encounter “what does it do?” and “how does it do it?” to better understand poetry as a unique form and to capture its unique essence in our own writing. You will begin the semester by demystifying this genre, unpacking preconceived notions about poetry. You will then transition into close reading and analysis, and you will write both critically and creatively in response to the poetry you study. Finally, you will finish the semester by preparing a portfolio of your own work. This is a course for artists and thinkers alike. You should expect to undertake a rigorous reading and response schedule, as well as look forward to the opportunity to hone your own voice on the page.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent.

Course Name: English Seminar: The Pleasures of Difficulty
Description: Do you want to challenge your mind with concepts that defy the typical, with texts that force you to slow down and puzzle through tangled thoughts? In this course, you will read, write about, and discuss texts from across genres –– fiction, nonfiction, poetry — that are, well,  difficult. That is to say, these are texts (and ways of reading them) that leave some work for you as a reader to do. This course is designed to teach you new ways to read, write, and think and to become more aware of yourself as a reader, writer, and thinker. What makes a text “difficult”? Why embrace difficulty? What reading and thinking strategies allow us to work with difficult texts? How does the process of overcoming difficulty contribute to our experience of literature? Here you will welcome difficulty as an expected guest in the learning process. You will work together to engage with complexity, observe closely, question skillfully, become aware of assumptions, adjust your expectations, and discover new things. Perhaps most important, since difficulty is a part of life and an essential part of the processes of intellectual growth and of creativity, the work you do in this course will allow you to discover the pleasures of difficulty. You will learn to rely on discussion and informal, exploratory writing as tools for thinking. Written work will include regular “difficulty papers” as well as critical and creative pieces. You will come away from this course with the skills and confidence to tackle anything you might want or need to read in the future –– and ready to take on all kinds of difficulty. Possible course texts include George Steiner’s “On Difficulty,” Gertrude Stein’s “Tender Buttons,” Virginia Woolf’s “To the Lighthouse,” Gabriel García Márquez’s “One Hundred Years of Solitude,” Italo Calvino’s “If on a winter’s night a traveler,” William Faulkner’s “The Sound and the Fury,” and Rebecca Solnit’s “Men Explain Things to Me.”
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: ENG 311, ENG 311LM, or equivalent. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.

Description: Starting with your background in natural sciences, you will add a social science and humanities approach to begin to understand the complexities of people’s relationships with the natural world and the challenges we face as individuals, as societies, and as a global community in charting a course for sustainable life on Earth. You will develop scientific literacy and communication skills through case studies, class discussions, and multimedia projects, culminating in a self-designed final project to pursue personal interests in more depth. You will become familiar with global changes in ecology, human populations, and resource availability over time. In particular, you will explore inequities in global systems and the disproportionate effects of a changing planet on vulnerable populations. Through readings and class discussions, you will explore topics such as the relationship of people with the natural world through time; ecology; population biology and human population issues; resource availability and use, including energy resources; pollution and waste; environmental ethics and environmental law; and loss of biodiversity. This course is a great option if you have a strong interest in sustainability and enjoy an interdisciplinary approach without a laboratory emphasis.
Credit: Prerequisite: BIO 311 or equivalent. This course does not award laboratory science credit. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs. Not open to students who have taken ENV 521 or equivalent.

Description: This course is taught at the same level as a standard college-level introductory geology course. You will explore the major concepts of physical geology through observation and interpretation, using the local area, Franklin County, as your laboratory. You will begin the semester practicing the scientific method and studying the evidence for many of our current theories about geologic time and the formation, structure, and history of the earth. You will have opportunities each week to identify common minerals and rock types during in-depth field trips to local outcrops. You will choose a research project to explore and present at the end of the course.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.

Course Name: The Science of Farming: Sustainable Land Use
Description: In The Science of Farming, you will take a deep dive into the science, culture, and realities of making the food we eat. You will apply the scientific method to study campus agricultural land use, monitor and document current crop and food production techniques, and identify improvements and solutions that can be put into immediate practice at the farm. Your work can make a difference in our school farm’s practices. Key concepts will include soil science, plant physiology, and horticulture — topics that allow you to apply your previous knowledge of biology and chemistry and to practice systems-thinking through ongoing hands-on learning experiences. You will also explore broader themes of sustainability, climate change, and ethical stewardship of the land and resources of the Connecticut River Valley.
Prerequisite: Prerequisites: BIO 311 or equivalent. Open only to juniors, seniors, and PGs participating in the Farm Semester Program. Taken concurrently with ENG 460 English Seminar: Reading and Writing the Land.

Description: The NMH campus will serve as a living laboratory in this place-based course applying environmental science principles to the school’s infrastructure and operations. You will learn the scientific principles, concepts, and methodologies to identify and analyze natural and human-made environmental problems and evaluate risks associated with their solutions. You will conduct field research and laboratory exercises and develop a familiarity with GIS mapping software to better understand ecology, population dynamics, sustainable resource use, global changes in air, and water and soil pollutants and their consequences. Advanced Environmental Science will introduce you to the content on the AP Environmental Science exam, but additional studying on your own would be necessary to be successful on the AP exam.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: B+ or better in BIO 311 and CHE 311 or equivalents and B average or better in high school English classes or departmental approval. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs. Not open to students who have taken ENV 411 or ENV 415.

Description: You will be introduced to topics in world history through historical inquiry that describe and explain critical moments in the world’s history. You will investigate, identify, and define significant global historical figures, events, and ideas that have shaped the past and the present. You will be introduced to relationships between various regions at different times in history, including the rise and fall of civilizations throughout the world. Your learning will culminate with an analysis of the challenges of life in a globalized world, including environmental, political, economic, cultural, and social issues. You will learn how to write a research paper, a requirement of the course.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. This course fulfills the 10th-grade history requirement if the returning student chooses not to take Humanities II. Open to 10th-graders.

Course Name: Humanities II: Topics in World History
Description:
The Humanities II program asks you to explore four essential questions: What is the story of power and powerlessness? What has created diversity and unity within and across traditions and cultures? What is progress and how and why do humans pursue it? How, then, shall we (I) live in relation to others and the planet? In this portion of Humanities II, you will be introduced to world history and historical inquiry through the use of primary and secondary source materials from the Western and non-Western world. The focus is on investigating critical moments in the world’s history. You will investigate, identify, and define significant global historical events, figures, and ideas that have shaped the past and continue to influence the present. You will learn how to write a research paper, a requirement of the course.
As part of the HUM II course, you have the opportunity to participate in a 10th-grade interdisciplinary travel program. Recent destinations include South Africa, Brazil, and Spain/Morocco. You simultaneously enroll in three courses for the semester: Humanities II: World History, Humanities II: World Religions, and Biology. There is a formal application process, and participation requires additional fees.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Required of all new 10th-graders except those enrolled in the ESOL program. Open to 10th-graders.

Description: This course is a survey of the history of the United States. You will cover topics including but not limited to contact and colonization, the causes and effects of the American Revolution, events leading up to the Civil War and its aftermath, the Industrial Revolution and the coming of age of the United States, the world wars, the Depression and the New Deal, the Cold War, and the Civil Rights Movement. You will be introduced to historical inquiry and creative investigation into the origins and character of American civilization. Writing and research assignments, including successful completion of a required research paper with a passing grade, emphasize the use of supporting evidence in clear, coherent essays in order to critically assess a variety of issues in United States history. Fulfills U.S. history requirement.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Open to all juniors and select seniors and PGs. Students who take HIS 312, HIS 311LM, or HIS 522 are not eligible for this course.

Description: Learn about the historical development of American national government and political behavior through a close examination of the three branches of government. You will consider political thought, political parties, interest groups, and other forces that have an impact on the political process in the United States. Additional topics covered include a look at individual rights and liberties as guaranteed by the Bill of Rights and honored by the courts, as well as the presidency. This course is not a general survey course of American history but rather an examination of political topics throughout American history and how they relate to your life today. Students must successfully complete and receive a passing grade on a required research paper. While this course fulfills the graduation requirement in U.S. history, it may also be taken as an elective by those who have already completed U.S. History.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Open to all juniors and select seniors and PGs. Students who take HIS 311, HIS 311LM, or HIS 522 are not eligible for this course.

Description: In this course, you will study the challenges facing the United States in the 21st century through four thematic modules. You’ll study post-World War II American leadership to build domestic and international institutions that address the threat of communism, promote economic development, and build international consensus, peace, and security. From there you will explore the evolution of containment policy during the Cold War with the Soviet Union and the complex relationship between foreign policy and American democracy. Next, you’ll investigate American policy in the Middle East and the eventual road to the tragedy of 9/11. You’ll conclude by studying post-9/11 foreign policy and the American attempt to “pivot” to Asia and meet China’s transformational economic growth and its growing influence in Asia and the rest of the developing world. Throughout the course, current events will be considered daily as you explore how foreign policy can meet the new challenges of reconsidering historic alliances, asset allocation, the COVID-19 pandemic, and a global recession.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs who have completed the U.S. History graduation requirement.

Course Name: The Ancient Mediterranean World: Kings, Oligarchs, and the Oppressed
Description: The philosophies and political systems established by the ancient cultures of the Mediterranean world remain both relevant and influential to all aspects of modern society. In this course, you will analyze primary sources such as Herodotus’ “Histories” and the Darius’ Behistun Inscription. You will also explore how the events and ideas of the ancient world echo through the present day. How did the militaristic Spartans and Assyrians influence modern notions of glory and nationalism? How did Cyrus the Great’s treatment of various ethnic groups in Persia help lead to the concept of civil rights? How did the trial of Socrates dictate modern notions of free speech? The Greek word “paideia” refers to the education of Greek youth in the hope of forging the ideal citizen. You will ask yourself what it meant for the ancients and what it means for you as a global citizen who wants to live with humanity and purpose.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs who have completed the U.S. History graduation requirement.

Advanced Studies in World History: Latin America
Description:
This course will explore the development of Latin America from the 19th century to contemporary times. You will probe the complex dynamics of land, race, power, and lingering inequality that has impacted competing visions for development, modernization, and democracy. The course will delve into the region’s economic relationship with the global economy, the consequences of climate change, the evolution of the Catholic Church and the rapid growth of evangelical Christians, the mobilization and barriers to democratic reform, growing movements of various marginalized groups, and the impact of U.S. foreign policy on the region. While studying these trends in modern Latin America, you will regularly integrate current events, literature, music, and art to enhance your understanding of the incredible mosaic of history and culture that defines Latin America today. You will investigate primary and secondary sources, think rigorously about Latin America from interdisciplinary and transnational perspectives, and produce an original research paper.
This course explores various regions of the world on a rotating basis. Past regions explored include East Asia (HIS 523) and Africa (HIS 524). Students may take this course multiple times, as long as they study a new region each time.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: Placement based on departmental recommendation. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs who have completed the U.S. History graduation requirement.

Credit: One credit: half-credit each in fall and spring semesters.

Description: This course introduces you to Latin grammar, syntax, and vocabulary while you study Roman civilization and culture. While Latin 111 is primarily a reading course, with a focus on preparing you to read the great literature of the classical tradition, there is also an introduction to spoken Latin. You will gain a broad overview of the systems of verbs, adjectives, and nouns in Latin. In addition, the course emphasizes the acquisition and refinement of the study skills necessary to master the forms and vocabulary of the language. A combination of classroom instruction and independent projects will help you explore the history and culture of the classical Roman world. This course will prepare you for Latin 211 but can also be viewed as a stand-alone introduction to the formal study of language and to the culture, history, and literature of classical Rome.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None.

Description: Latin II continues the study of Latin grammar, syntax, and vocabulary begun in Latin I. You will complete your overview of all of the declensions of nouns and all of the tenses of verbs in active and passive voices. Subordinate clauses and subjunctive mood are introduced. You will extend your reading skills and your knowledge of Roman history and culture through a combination of independent projects and engagement with authentic Latin literature. Description:
In Advanced Calculus I and II, you will cover the essential topics across the first two semesters of college-level introductory calculus. The course will take you through a rigorous exploration of calculus concepts, including the study of theorems, their proofs, and a wide array of applications. Your study will include limits, continuity, and the fundamentals of derivatives and their applications, as well as the principles of antidifferentiation and integration. You will tackle practical problems such as optimization and related rate issues and engage in curve sketching.
The curriculum also focuses on the analytical and numerical solutions of simple differential equations, incorporating both traditional methods and tools like slope fields and Euler’s method. A significant emphasis is placed on sequences and series, teaching various tests for convergence and the representation of functions through Taylor and Maclaurin series. Additionally, you will apply calculus concepts to parametric and polar functions. By completing Advanced Calculus I and II, you will be thoroughly prepared to take the BC level of the AP Calculus exam, with no need for additional preparation.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: MAT 421 or equivalent. Placement based on screening process.

You will learn essential choral skills such as vocal technique, breathing technique, how to read music, and how to be a good performer. You will sing a wide repertoire from sacred, secular, and world literature and experience the joy of collaborative music making in a small ensemble. This group performs at school concerts as well as at off-campus events. As a member of the NMH Singers, you will also participate in the Concert Choir. Auditions take place in the previous spring and at the start of the school year. This course may be repeated by the student who wishes to continue developing skills as a singer and performer.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: Audition.

Description: In this course, you will learn how to build, code, and operate a robot. You will design your own VEX V5 robot and explore how to code using the engineering design process. You will study the basic design-thinking process, the use of multiple types of sensors, and the foundational coding and Python needed to engage in hands-on projects that get more complex the more you learn. You will also learn the history of robotics and the ethical considerations of using artificial intelligence in our society now and in the future.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Open to 9th-graders only.

Description: This course is designed for 9th-graders who have already completed Algebra I and 10th-graders who have already taken Biology. Physics is the foundational course in the NMH science curriculum and helps you develop problem-solving skills and get experience collecting and analyzing data from laboratory experiments. You will investigate a variety of topics in the classroom and lab, including forces, motion, and energy, comprising mechanics, heat, electricity, and magnetism. Students who achieve at a high level and complete supplementary honors assignments might be recommended for honors-level science courses.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: MAT 111 or equivalent. Open to 9th- or 10th-graders. Placement based on screening process.

Description: Using your investigation-based textbook for background information, you will use a wide variety of learning tools, including videos, models, class discussions, research, and our on-campus observatory, to study the traditional sky and constellations, the solar system, stars and stellar evolution, black holes, galaxies, exoplanets, and cosmology. You will learn to use several software tools for sky-simulation work, modeling current discoveries and providing up-to-date astronomical catalogs.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: PHY211 and MAT 311 or equivalents. Open to juniors, seniors, PGs, and recommended sophomores.

Description: This course is an intensive introduction to physics for students with a strong background in mathematics and/or students who have had previous coursework in physics. Topics include one- and two-dimensional motion, Newton’s laws, thermal energy, light, electricity, and relativity. Through these topics, you will learn how physics asks questions about the natural world, and you will use these questions to learn essential science skills. Unit projects are a focus of the course, as you will apply your conceptual knowledge to investigate real-life applications and solve problems.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: A- or better in MAT 311, or B+ or better in MAT 321. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs, and to 9th- and 10th-graders with departmental approval. Placement based on screening process.

Description: Advanced Physics: Mechanics is an algebra-based course that will prepare you for college-level physics. The course focuses primarily on the mechanics portion of Advanced Physics. As you study the concepts of the course, you will focus on lab technique, science practices, and real-life application projects with mathematical problem-solving. Lab investigations will solidify your understanding of topics such as Newtonian mechanics, wave motion, and sound. For certain units of the course, you may opt to incorporate calculus to tackle calculus-based mechanics.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: B+ or better in MAT411 or equivalent, B or better in honors equivalents, and a B+ or better in PHY211 or PHY421 or equivalent. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs who meet the prerequisites or with departmental approval.

Course Name: Advanced Physics II: Electricity and Magnetism
Description: This college-level, calculus-based course is a good fit if you are interested in pursuing more advanced physics or engineering in college. You will start with Newtonian mechanics and spend the bulk of the course studying electricity and magnetism through the lens of field theory, focusing on Gauss’ law for electric fields and Ampere’s law for magnetic fields. In addition, you will work with resistor- and capacitor-based circuit analysis. You will be introduced to and learn to use appropriate technology in laboratory investigations to study these phenomena. Your skill in working through complex problems will be greatly developed as you apply concepts to problems and investigations. If you have progressed beyond calculus, you can work even further on electrodynamics by applying multivariable techniques.
Prerequisite: Prerequisites: B+ or better in MAT 515 or equivalent; a B+ or better in PHY531 or equivalent, or an A- or better in PHY211 or PHY421 or equivalent. PHY 531 is recommended. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs who meet the prerequisites or with departmental approval.

Humanities I: Religious Studies and Philosophy
Description: Ninth-grade Religious Studies and Philosophy is part of the Humanities I program, which asks you to explore four essential questions: Who am I? What does it mean to be human? What is my place? How, then, shall I live? You will learn the key concepts of worldview, ritual, symbol, myth, secularity, ethics, and epistemology (how we know what we know). In addition, you will examine the relationship between human beings and their environment by exploring your own sense of place, both in the home that you come from and your new home in the Northfield Mount Hermon community. As in any humanities course, you will read important texts, think critically about them, and discuss them with your classmates. You will also write personal reflections and analytical essays to explain your convictions.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Required of all 9th-graders except those enrolled in the ESOL program.

Description:
World Religions is part of the Humanities II program, which asks you to explore four essential questions: What is the story of power and powerlessness? What has created diversity and unity within and across traditions and cultures? What is progress, and how and why do humans pursue it? How, then, shall we (I) live in relation to others and the planet? To gain a richer understanding of people, you will explore the beliefs and practices of religious traditions such as Indigenous religious traditions, Hinduism, Buddhism, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam, paying special attention to the internal diversity and historical evolution of those traditions. As in any humanities course, you will read important texts, think critically about them, and discuss them with your classmates. In addition, you will learn how to write a research paper, a requirement of the course. Assignments and activities are designed to build on concepts and skills developed in Humanities I while also introducing integrated humanities study to new 10th-graders.
As part of the HUM II course, you have the opportunity to participate in a 10th-grade interdisciplinary travel program. Recent destinations include South Africa, Brazil, and Spain/Morocco. You simultaneously enroll in three courses for the semester: Humanities II: World History, Humanities II: World Religions, and Biology. There is a formal application process, and participation requires additional fees.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Required of all new 10th-graders except those enrolled in the ESOL program. Open to 10th-graders.

Description: If you have wondered about the nature of reality or what it means to know something, then you belong in a philosophy class. The process of thinking philosophically requires you to ask big questions and examine your most basic assumptions in order to build a wise foundational understanding of important concepts such as reality, knowledge, justice, art, suffering, and politics. You will learn how to question and reason philosophically, which will enable you to think critically and systematically about whatever it is you choose to think about.

Description: This course will give you an opportunity to dive into the religious practices, myths, and history of resilience among three Native tribes indigenous to the North American continent. You will have the opportunity to learn about unique beliefs and experiences of each tribe before, during, and after colonial impact through the use of primary sources, scholarly perspectives, and the valuable input of members of each tribe, both past and present. Throughout this course, you will be exposed to the rich history of a people often ignored and also see how these people continue to live and thrive today. Through identifying and understanding the shifts in religious practices in these tribes over time, you will consider how colonization dramatically impacted Native peoples and also how these same people survived and continue to flourish. Lastly, you will utilize what you learn in this class to do your own research on a fourth tribe of your choosing, allowing you to both apply what you learn in class and explore a group of your own interest throughout the length of the semester.
Prerequisite: Prerequisite: None. Open to juniors, seniors, and PGs.
